title: Science / Science & Exploration
author: Cyrus Farivar
description: Serving the Technologist for more than a decade. IT news, reviews, and analysis.
cleaned_text: Science / Science & Exploration - [California governor signs bill eliminating personal vaccine exemptions](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/california-governor-signs-bill-eliminating-personal-vaccine-exemptions/) Gov. Brown: "The science is clear that vaccines dramatically protect children." - [Increased brain connectivity eases teenage impatience](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/increased-brain-connectivity-eases-teenage-impatience/) Communication between brain regions allows adults to better consider the future. - [Familiar fishes found opportunity in mass extinction](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/familiar-fishes-found-opportunity-in-mass-extinction/) Like mammals, ray-finned fishes may have hit the big time after the big hit. - [Supreme Court rejects EPA's process for regulating power plant pollution](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/supreme-court-rejects-epas-process-for-regulating-power-plant-pollution/) But limits on mercury emissions will undoubtably be back. - [The mystery of Kawasaki disease](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/the-mystery-of-kawasaki-disease/) Fungal toxin? Carpet-cleaning chemical? No one knows why this heart disease impacts kids. - [The violent origin of quasars](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/the-violent-origin-of-quasars/) Hubble shows that quasars get their fuel when their host galaxies collide. - [SpaceX launch failure blamed on upper stage oxygen tank](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/spacex-launch-failure-blamed-on-upper-stage-oxygen-tank/) ISS crew good on supplies until October; hardware will be harder to replace. - [Solar-powered plane takes off on potential record-breaking trans-Pacific flight](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/solar-powered-plane-takes-off-on-potential-record-breaking-trans-pacific-flight/) Records: Longest-duration solo flight, farthest distance from a solar-powered aircraft. - [Falling into a black hole may convert you into a hologram](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/falling-into-a-black-hole-may-convert-you-into-a-hologram/) Or you may hit a firewall of doom. Physicists are still debating this one. - [New "corner cloak" directs light around sharp bends](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/new-corner-cloak-directs-light-around-sharp-bends/) Light goes around corners as if they're not there. - [SpaceX Falcon breaks up during ISS resupply launch](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/spacex-falcon-breaks-up-during-iss-resupply-launch/) Third resupply mission to fail in the past year. - [Microsoft's HoloLens is heading to the Space Station tomorrow aboard SpaceX CRS-7](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2015/06/microsofts-hololens-is-heading-to-the-space-station-tomorrow-on-spacex-crs-7/) Falcon 9 main stage will also attempt to land on a barge. Third time lucky! Paul Sutter walks us through the future of climate change—and things aren't great This episode of Edge of Knowledge focuses on our rapidly transforming world. - [Microsoft's HoloLens is heading to the Space Station tomorrow aboard SpaceX CRS-7](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2015/06/microsofts-hololens-is-heading-to-the-space-station-tomorrow-on-spacex-crs-7-2/) Falcon 9 main stage will also attempt to land on a barge. Third time lucky! - [How breaking a glacier makes the Earth quake](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/how-breaking-a-glacier-makes-the-earth-quake/) Calving icebergs squish glaciers and pull on the Earth. - [Controversial trial of GM crop shows no benefits](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/controversial-trial-of-gm-crop-shows-no-benefits/) But the trials weren't entirely conclusive. - [Study claims 1 in 4 cancer research papers contains faked data](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/study-claims-1-in-4-cancer-research-papers-contains-faked-data/) A closer look at the results suggests things are bad, but not quite that bad. - [Too much brownie, not enough pot: Most medical edible labels mislead](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/new-study-finds-60-of-medical-cannabis-edibles-overstate-thc-levels/) Products tested in LA, San Francisco, and Seattle were seriously underdosed. - [A detailed photo tour of NASA's space shuttle cockpit trainer](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/a-detailed-photo-tour-of-nasas-space-shuttle-cockpit-trainer/) Before it was decommissioned, we got to sit in the pilot's seat and ask questions. - [Finding the head of an ancient, hallucinatory mini-monster](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/finding-the-head-of-an-ancient-hallucinatory-mini-monster/) Hallucigenia had been a bizarre collection of headless parts until now. - [Relativity's time dilation may limit the quantum world](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/relativitys-time-dilation-may-limit-the-quantum-world/) Theoretical calculations suggest time dilation may cause systems to decohere. - [Review: PBS' "First Peoples" tracks our arrival on every continent](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/review-pbs-first-peoples-tracks-our-arrival-on-every-continent/) A one-stop shop for key events in humanity's history. - [Australia slashes its renewable energy target by nearly 20%](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/australia-slashes-its-renewable-energy-target-by-nearly-20/) Will appoint a "wind farm commissioner" to field complaints about turbines, too. - [Netherlands loses landmark global warming case, ordered to cut emissions](https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2015/06/netherlands-loses-landmark-global-warming-case-ordered-to-cut-emissions/) Ruling could set a very important precedent in Europe and around the world. - [European skeleton had Neanderthal ancestor less than 200 years earlier](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/european-skeleton-had-neanderthal-ancestor-less-than-200-years-earlier/) But its population didn't give rise to any group in Europe that we've looked at. - [Will Google's research-grade fitness band be its biomed breakthrough?](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/google-aims-at-researchkit-but-past-biomedical-adventures-havent-prospered/) Google has had plenty of biomedical failures. - [Changes large and small causing recyclers to struggle](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/changes-large-and-small-causing-recyclers-to-struggle/) Low energy prices, manufacturing changes make the economics challenging. - [NASA lays out its plans for a Europa orbiter](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/nasa-lays-out-its-plans-for-a-europa-orbiter/) Agency decides what to take with it to the body most likely to contain life. - [Individual neurons tell us whether we remember something](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/individual-neurons-tell-us-whether-we-remember-something/) And, at the same time, indicate how confident we should be in that judgment. - [Magnetic mirror holds promise for fusion](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/magnetic-mirror-holds-promise-for-fusion/) In a Polywell design, a high-density plasma excludes magnetic field, traps itself. - [Counting crows' neurons work just like yours](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/counting-crows-neurons-work-just-like-yours/) Researchers find out how a crow's brain recognizes numbers. - [Gene mutation in Ebola outbreak provides epidemiological insight](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/gene-mutation-in-ebola-outbreak-provides-epidemiological-insight/) Insight into the most recent Ebola outbreak could inform future intervention. - [Pope makes ethical case for action on climate change](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/pope-makes-ethical-case-for-action-on-climate-change/) Papal document on the environment urges care for "our Sister, Mother Earth." - [BBC built a mind-control TV prototype as a "possible future interface"](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2015/06/bbc-creates-mind-control-tv-prototype-as-a-possible-future-interface/) A custom version of iPlayer, plus a consumer-grade EEG. Clunky, but it works. - [Genome of enigmatic Kennewick skeleton confirms he was Native American](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/genome-of-enigmatic-kennewick-skeleton-confirms-he-was-native-american/) Data also provides insight into the peopling of the continent. - [Researchers weigh up a Mars-sized exoplanet](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/researchers-weigh-up-a-mars-sized-exoplanet/) Part of a three planet system first spotted by Kepler. - [The dangerous power of health media: 28,000 quit statins after scare documentary](https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/06/the-dangerous-power-of-health-media-28000-quit-statins-after-scare-documentary/) It's vital that people discuss medical decisions with health professionals.
